page.title: 18NATURE RESERVE ON ARNE
page.content: The path turns inland from the beach and back to dry heathland,climbing up to the top of a hill.From this vantage point, most of the Harbour,and the built-up areas of Poole to the North East can be seen. Leaving the hill,the track winds through ling heather,and dwarf gorse. Both Maritime and Scots Pine can be seen.Here the trail divides and a short route continues along the main track through dry heathland. A longer route leads through wet heathland,where cross leaved heath(a damp-loving heather)sundew and heath rush live,and then past fresh water pools.These were formed from old World War 2 bomb craters,and provide a habitat for many different species of dragonfly,whirligig beetles,and midge larvae.
